text:
I made this yesterday for the first time - EXCELLENT!!!!!   Based on reviews I read I did the following: 1) used three sweet sausages and two hot ones (which I first cooked in my George Foreman Grille)  2) used 2 cloves of garlic, used 2 more cups of broth*(chicken),  3) used two cans of stewed tomatoes, 4) used 1 pkg of frozen spinach -- not fresh  5) added 1/2 cup of raw orzo noodles,  6) added 1 cubed potato,  7)added 1 chopped onion,  8) did not use the 1/4 teaspoon of salt.     *NOTE:  for the extra broth I make my own by using Herb-Ox Granulated VERY LOW SODIUM - only 5 grams of sodium per teaspoon compared to ca. 800 grams in the regular kind - 26 servings per jar.

text:
This is our family's favorite soup.  We've made it a dozen times.  Be sure to buy sausage without the MSG to avoid the headaches and allergic reations.  I've made this substituting potatoes for beans, okra for zuchini, pintos for northern beans, adding rice, etc.  It always turns out delicious and satisfying.  Don't put the spinach in until the last few minutes so that it stays green and firmer.  Frozen is great, but make sure it's chopped.  The big, fat leaves don't work as well.     This soup also freezes well.  We had a pot of it last night that I had frozen two weeks ago.

text:
I would give this recipe 6 stars if I could!  I make it at least once a month, even in the Summertime.  A few changes I've made over time:  I add a chopped onion and double the garlic.  I use HOT Italian sausage (do this if you like a little extra kick).  I use 3 cans of beef broth, and make sure it is LOW SODIUM--I think this is crucial to the success of the recipe, because it is too salty with regular broth.  Delete the 1/4 t salt altogether, unless you feel it needs it at the end.  You can always add salt, but you can't take it away.  I also add 1/2 C of small pasta, whatever I have on hand (macaroni works fine, or use something else to be more elaborate) at the end of the cooking time.  If you'd like to do this, make sure you cook the pasta before adding the spinach.  Karen--thank you for a recipe that has become a household staple for us!

text:
Modest, unassuming ingredients that pack a punch of flavor for the unsuspecting taste tester.  I dislike reviewers who considerably change a recipe and then rate it on their modifications, but this time, I couldn't seem to help myself...  Doubled the recipe, and used one pound of hot and one of sweet sausage, extra clove of garlic, added celery, small red potatoes, cannelli beans as that's the only type I had on hand, diced canned tomatoes with basil, oregano and garlic added and omitted the salt.  Turned off the heat and added thinly sliced zuchinni and the fresh spinach 10 minutes prior to serving.  Absolutely superb flavor!!!  Thanks Sallyjun for the submission!

country:
None
text:
Nice, basic recipe for the humble but delicious Minestrone, with plenty of wiggle room for your own creativity or to use whatever vegetables are to your liking or what you have on hand. I made my own beef broth and along with the sausage I included the beef from the meaty bones I used. Added celery, onions and mushrooms with the carrots, along with some Tuscan seasoning. I used cannellini beans since I prefer them, and at the end threw in ditalini pasta (about 1 c. uncooked) which I had cooked ahead of time so the pasta wouldn't absorb too much of the broth.  Instead of the canned tomatoes I used tomatoes I had put up from my garden. There really is no right or wrong when making Italian soups like this, and the fun thing about it is that it never turns out exactly the same way twice! Sometimes I like to add a glug of red wine, or maybe rice, or various shapes of soup pasta. I did use fresh spinach this time, but Swiss Chard or escarole are nice too! To truly be authentic, sprinkle each serving with good, freshly grated Parmesan or Romano cheese!

text:
Wow!  Unbelievably good, even better than I thought it would be - a definite keeper and company-quality recipe.  In fact, I think this is the best recipe I've gotten from this site.  I added the browned sausage and the rest of the ingredients (plus an onion, a teaspoon of minced garlic - and red pepper instead of green) to the crockpot, and cooked it on low for 5 hours.  I seasoned it with oregano, parsley, and rosemary.  Then I stirred in a half cup or so cooked, drained ditalini before serving.  Served with garlic bread, of course, just wonderful.

Excellent!!  I don't have any idea what possessed me to make this soup.  It is nothing that I would normally be drawn to.  Well.. I love it!!  Most soups that I make take hours to cook.  Not this.. within the hour it was ready to eat and the house smelled wonderful.  Changes that I made:  I mixed both hot and mild sausage.  Added onion and extra garlic when browning meat.  Like others... I added additional can beef broth and tomatoe.  I eliminated the zuccini and any additional salt.  When I added the beans (which i never thought i'd like but they add a nice touch) I also added some very small pasta.  The result... delish!!!! Can't wait to serve it to my guests tomorrow!!!

At first I thought no way could this be so tasty. Yeah, it's packed with veggies and sausage but there are no herbs and seasoning, just salt and pepper. Then I made it exact to the recipe. I always like to do that first. Reviews are filled with people who will happily give 5 stars but change 35% of the recipe. So I made it...and it was great! It's a really quick and basic recipe but it yields a lot of flavor. It got a thumbs up from myself and my soup fanatic bf. You can dress it up or dress it down but either way it's a winner.

country:

text:
I made this soup last night and it was FABULOUS.  My husband said it was by far the best new thing I've made in awhile.  Even my 8 year old raved about it.  I made a few changes based on my families likes/dislikes.  I doubled the recipe so we would have leftovers (they won't last long!). I omited the spinich, beans and zucchini  but added in a whole chopped onion and a green pepper while browning the meat (I used HOT italian sausage instead of regular) as well as probably used about 5 cloves of garlic.  Instead of simmering on the stove, I then transferred it all to a crockpot with the various liquids. I also added chopped up potatoes to substitute for the starch from the beans and a large fresh garden tomato in big chunks . I put the crockpot on high until it started bubbling (about 2 hours) and then reduced to low for another few hours until the potatoes were tender.  We served with warm crusty french bread and it was WONDERFUL!  I have a feeling this will be replacing chili many cold nights this winter!

text:
love the recipe- but I do it southern style! collards instead of spinach, butter-beans, squash. As long as you use the foundation combo of Italian sausage + broth + tomatoes + greens you are good to go. I literally hunt around for anything veggie that needs to be used up, add whatever canned or frozen veggies I have on hand.  I also like to add a glass of red wine, pasta or quinoa, and more Italian seasoning. This freezes well, I freeze it in single servings and take it to lunch when the weather is dreary.

text:
I made this with half sweet turkey sausage and half hot turkey sausage.  I wondered about the flavor combination of turkey sausage and beef broth, but the flavors came together really well in the last 5 minutes.  Please be sure to let the soup sit off the heat after the spinach goes in--that's when the flavors meld and the soup flavors really bloom.  We don't like mushy zucchini, so I cut mine into 1 inch pieces.  Really good, satisfying soup.

text:
Awesome base recipe!  I really liked this soup. It seems like as long as you use this base of italian sausage, tomatoes beef broth and beans, then you can put in anything you like. I didn't have the right beans. so I used black beans. I didn't have zucchini or spinach, so I used 2 potatoes, an ear of corn, 2 stalks celery, a large bell pepper, and 1/2 c onion. still great. I used italian sausage bratwurst type sausage links and just browned them well and then cut them into slices. This made pretty circles of sausage in the soup. For the second time, day before Christmas when we have a crowd of people over, I'm using twice the veggies and broth and tomatoes and still just 1 lb of sausage and adding a bag of mezzaluna four cheese ravioli. I'm sure that will work too. (edited review-it worked fine with more veggies and small cheese filled ravioli, if you have a crowd and want to extend your soup!)

text:
A great soup! I needed to add significantly more broth because of my additional add-ins (cooked elbows, sauteed onions, celery), along with everything else (sausage, carrots, zucchini, spinach, beans) so plan accordingly. I also found after adding all the beef broth the tomato flavor had diminished so I poured in some Spicy V-8 juice - gave it a kick! Also added dried oregano and coarse pepper - no additional salt. Hope it freezes well - it makes plenty!

This soup was an afterthought to fill out a rather skimpy meal. Except for the beans, which a reviewer suggested could be replaced by potatoes, I had all the other ingredients. As my Italian sausages were all hot I was unsure of the level of spicy heat. I needn't have worried. The soup was absolutely perfect. A great balance of all the flavours. What a wonderful surprise. *29 October 2015. It's been a long time since preparing this recipe.

I've just made this soup and wanted to say that it's as good, if not better,  on this rather chilly Canadian autumn  day.  My kitchen smells so good. I can hardly wait for dinner.

text:
Amazing soup - eating it as I type and can't wait for second helpings.  Recipe made even simpler by using my slow cooker. Browned the Italian sausage beforehand, then threw everything in the slow cooker on low for six hours.  Added onion and extra garlic.  Also substituted frozen chopped spinach for fresh.  Finally, in order to prevent the zucchini from becoming mushy I added it to the slow cooker in the last half hour.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow this soup is wonderful!  I made a few changes, based on other reviews and personal preferences, but I'm sure this would be great as written.  I used 1 link hot Italian sausage and 1 link of smoked sausage, because that is what I had.  I used a 28 oz, can of crushed tomatoes to give it a little more body and  added some Italian seasoning instead of the stewed tomatoes, but no salt added.  I used a 32 oz. box of beef broth.  I sauteed 1 chopped onion, the carrots and 3 cloves of garlic.  I added 1 cubed potato and 3/4 cup of small pasta along with the beans and zucchini.  I didn't have any fresh spinach so I used about 1/2 box frozen, squeezed out and chopped.  When it was done I sprinkled freshly grated parmesan.  It was absolutely delish!  I will be making this again and again!

This soup is fantastic!  I've made it 3 times in the past 6 weeks, and it's on next week's menu as well.  I did make one adjustment based on personal preference, but I subbed Kale for the Spinach. userID:
2652014
Display Name:
Judy Greening Stocker
isPro:
False
followersCount:
6
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
102
favoritesCount:
1050
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2157478.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used 3 hot and 2 mild Italian Sausage links with casings removed.  Browned them in dutch oven sprayed with Pam and then cut them with spatula into chunks.  Added about 1 cup chopped onion and 3 cloves minced garlic.  Cooked this for a couple minutes and then added 2 cans Italian stewed tomatoes, the carrots and 4 cups chicken broth.  I added about 3 teaspoons beef base (I didn't have any beef broth) and 3 diced red potatoes.  Cooked this for about 20 minutes then added the zucchini and beans.  Cooked another 20 minutes or so and then added thawed frozen spinach and about 1/2 cup orzo.  Cooked another 20 minutes.  Turned heat off and let it sit for about an hour before eating.  TO DIE FOR GOOD!!!!!!!!!  Sorry about the changes, but I just couldn't resist adding onion!  The other small changes made for a delicious soup.  I'm sure it is good without these changes, but I will make it my way from now on as it was so good.  Thanks for the recipe!

I made this soup for dinner last night, and I have to say it is delicious. I made it pretty much the way the recipe is written however, I added chopped onion, chopped fresh oregano and basil, 4 cloves of garlic,and used diced tomatoes as that is what I had available.To give it a little kick I threw in some crushed red pepper, and omitted the salt as others suggested. I also added an extra cup of vegetable broth, in addition to the beef broth. This is definitely a keeper recipe and I look forward to  making this many more times.

text:
This is so good. I added an extra can of beef broth plus a second can of northern beans. Used frozen chopped spinach and then topped each serving off with dried Parmesan cheese. We're having it again tonight. Only thing I noticed was it takes longer to make than I thought it would, but it's worth the time. This is now a regular meal for us--highly recommend! Update 1/3/11 -- Tonight made it with hot Italian sausage, not mild, and it was so much better with the hot. Before, it was a pleasant soup. Now, outtasight (do people even say that anymore? Mercifully, not often). ;0) Have left out the spinach the last 2 times I've made it; we couldn't really taste it, and don't miss it.

text:
This recipe has been in my box for over two years, I finally made it. I have to say that when I tasted it early in the prep process I was less than thrilled. I felt as though it was a mistake making this. The finished product proved that wrong. All I can say is Wow! I did tweak it to my taste just a bit. First I more than doubled almost tripled the amount of water in it because the flavor was just so strong. I also added a few stalks of celery and two medium size onions. Other than that I stuck to the recipe. Next time I will not add ANY salt due to the content of salt in the sausage and beef broth. The spinach really brought the flavor home for me. The soup wouldn't be the same without it. This is for sure a keeper and this will be in a ton of people's email inbox  tomorrow morning.

userID:
4911216
Display Name:
designingstuff
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1

0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
137
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
One of my favorite recipies, esp. in the winter!  I did make a few changes:  added more carrots (I like it sweet), 2 cans of chicken broth in addition to the beef broth, more zuccini, and I've removed all the casing off the saussages before slicing them up.  Canned beans I've tried are kidney (adds more color) & garbonzo  --  depending on what I have on hand.  Instead of spinich I've also used collard greens.  I've made a meat-free version of this using veg. broth & vegetarian Italian saussage.  I add 1-2 TBS of Italian seasoning in the beginning, and as for the "saussage", I brown, set it aside and added it back to the pot during the last 15 min. of cooking  to reheat (prevents the "saussage" from breaking down.  This recipe seems bullet-proof -- it's always turned out great, even when I simmered it for  an hour.  I've served this at dinner parties and most end up having seconds; finicky kids seem to like it too!

text:
Thanks for the great soup recipe.  I did add onions and fresh mushrooms.  I also followed the advice of others to use low sodium broth.  It definatley had plenty of salt.  I made the soup early in the day then cooled it and skimmed the fat off of the top. I drained the sausage after browning but there was still a lot of grease.  I also added a can of black beans instead of the great northern.  The soup was even better the next day. I have tried making this soup with turkey sausage and it was ok but it is definatley better with regular sausage.  The turkey sausage was kind of rubbery.

There was plenty of left overs too since I doubled the batch!   Thank you!

Great basic recipe that you can alter based on your taste and what you have on hand. Definitely a keeper...thanks for sharing!

The first words out of my husbands mouth were "I think this is the best soup I ever ate"!!!  Some changes: Two cloves of garlic and a small chopped onion.  Can of diced tomatoes drained instead of stewed.  One more can of broth.  No salt or pepper.  Potatoes instead of beans. About 15 minutes before I was going to serve I added the spinach and some small pasta (already cooked).  Served with some Warm Italian Bread!!  Fantastic Soup for a nice fall or winter night!!  I can't wait to make it again

This soup is EXCELLENT...I have my family requesting I make it.  I did make minor changes...I use a little oil when I brown the sausage and 3 cloves of garlic...I use four cans of beef broth because I add cooked cheese tortellini before serving....I use fresh spinach but I slice the spinach in strips and use about 3 cups...if you want to make Italian sausage soup...this is the one to try...you will not be disappointed...I myself are not a soup lover but I LOVE THIS SOUP!!

Such a delicious soup from such simple ingredients! I used 50% less sodium beef broth and didn't need to add more salt. None
text:
Great easy, full-flavored soup! I use turkey sausage which I prefer. I add red pepper and a bit of hot sauce as I brown the sausage, garlic and onion. For veggies, I use celery, mushrooms, red and green pepper because they all reheat very well. I used two cans of garbanzo beans instead of great northern beans. I use diced tomatoes with basil, garlic and oregano (Del Monte brand) which adds a more flavor than one would expect. I serve with a salad for a lower-carb, healthy meal...

text:
Do you ever come home tired, starving and wishing that Prince Charming had dinner on the table ? Well keep wishing but in the mean time GO MAKE THIS SOUP! It's sooo good and sooo EZ. I used Jimmy Dean sausage roll and added a small cubed potato. Chill so you can take off the excess fat, then put into 2 cup storage containers and off to the freezer. Need a meal ??? Nuke a container of soup, grab a piece of toast and a glass of milk - you'll be a happy camper in under 10 minutes (no Prince needed!).

text:
You say to use the juice in the can of beans.  My advice:  taste the juice in any canned veggies/beans one time and you'll never use it again.  It's nasty.  Always, always dump veggies/beans, etc., into a collander and rinse well with cold water.

This was the first soup of my year of weekly soups.  The soup was by far the best soup I have ever made.  I added some extra veggies to help add some nutritional value.  My TOP suggestion would be drain the sausage if cooked on a stove top.  My soup was kind of greasy because I did not drain, however the flavor was too good, so I overlooked that small fact.  I look to alter this recipe in the future with other veggies.  Very good.

text:
Excellent!  My family loved this soup.  Really easy to make.  Fresh spinach is best, added at the end as suggested.  I added a few sliced red potatoes for extra heartiness.  I used ground italian sausage which had a nicer texture than the skinned sausage and also gave me a nice sausage flavor in every bite. I also used a lower sodium swanson's beef broth in the carton rather than the concentrated salty broth in the cans.  The great thing about this soup, is that you can make alot of substitutions and still have a nice and hearty soup.  It also made my house smell so good as I was preparing it.

country:
None
text:
I made this yesterday and its all gone today! Very good and not difficult to make at all, just chopping the veggies. I live in Germany so I can not buy Italian sausage so I used Gehacktes which is raw ground pork meat, very lean and has lots of garlic in it where I purchase it from. I hate when people modify a recipe and then rate it but I have no choice as I can not always get the ingredients. I opted against adding fennel to the Gehacktes as my husband hates it. I also added green and red peppers which needed to be used, and some celery stalks as they had to be used as well and which also made up for the lacking fennel. I did not use any salt and the soup was a dream. My husband raved about it all evening. Thanks for sharing this recipe will be making it again and again. Its also difficult to find such large quantites of Beef Broth over here so I used from Rewe Gemsefond mit Verjus. Can never go wrong with that great broth. This soup is so hearty you don't even need bread or a salad to compliment it

text:
This is so good! Even the kids love it. I like to cook the sausage, and then throw everything in the crockpot. I used 4 fresh large tomatoes instead of canned because we have them from the garden. I added the zucchini about mid-day. I added some leftover brown rice too for extra fill and fiber. If you add cooked rice, only add it about an hour or two before you eat, or it may soak up too much juice. I may add Quinoa next time.  This is a good base all on it's own.

text:
This is an awesome recipe! Thx 'SALLYJUN' for sharing. Great base soup that is exceedingly easy to adjust according to your taste. I decided to add 2 packages Italian sausage 1 sweet & 1 hot, like many other review's suggested, the flavors balance each other out. I also added red potatoes sliced paper thin, using a pampered chef tool, and left the skin on.  And, Lastly, because I don't really care for spinach in soup I subbed kale, which worked perfectly.  All the flavors meld beautifully together, definitely a keeper.

text:
SOOO tasty! My husband (Mr. Don't Try Anything New) said this is a keeper--make it again. I served this last week for company and got a rave review from all. Changes: no spinach, more garlic (always!), onions, crushed red pepper (spiced it up!), small shell pasta at the end, extra zucchini & carrots. I used sweet Italian turkey sausage and added an additional can of chicken broth (1-1/2 recipe) and served it with garlic/cheese bread. This is one of the most flavorful soups I've ever had. We ate it again last night as left-overs and I think it might have even been better than the first time! Thanks for the recipe AND the suggestions :-)

city:

country:

text:
I made this hearty soup over the weekend and the prep time was so quick and easy!  To cut prep time, I bought pre-sliced carrot chips and pre-cut and washed spinach.  I also added a can of water and one beef boullion cube in addition to the two cans of low-sodium beef broth because I felt that it was so loaded with veggies/meat that it needed more liquid.  I used a hot sausage mix from the butcher and it really gave the soup great flavor.  In all, this took me 30 minutes total...painless even for a weeknight dinner!  And full of flavor.  5 stars!

I also did not add salt and used low sodium broth.  Needless, to say the soup was great.  I won first place over 30 other contestants.

text:
I have made this soup many times since I found this recipe about a year ago.  It is wonderful. I find myself stocking up on the ingredients when I'm grocery shopping.  Oh course, I change things a bit.  Don't keep canned bullion so I use beef bullion cubes instead.  Also cut the carrots down to one carrot to lower the carb count.  I also use half yellow squash and half zucchini for added color.  Have discovered that it works just as well with frozen squash.  It doesn't matter if the sausage is hot or mild--whatever is available.  I don't bother with salt & pepper, however.  It is plenty spicy.  Thanks for a great meal!

text:
I usually will let a dish with tomato age for a day before eating. This works especially well for this recipe for a couple of reasons; once cold the fat hardens and stays on top making it very easy to remove to create a lower fat content. Second the aging allows the flavors to blend together nicely. I did add the zucchini and spinach just before serving the following day.     
A very nice recipe, if you look for 'keepers' this will be one.

Display Name:
Julia@foxtuity

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok people, the recipe as-is is excellent.  Don't change everything then say "it was great."  When you change everything it becomes a different recipe.  Just saying.  I also love onions, and potatoes, but didn't add them to this - and let me say, it was really, really, good.  I used spicy Italian sausage, which is exactly right if you like that little kick.  I didn't have straight up spinach, but a mix of baby greens including spinach, so that was a change and I'm sure I would love it even more with only spinach. Regarding the zucchini so many people eliminate - don't! Chopped small and cooked til tender, you can't taste it by itself, but it definitely adds exactly what it is supposed to, and you don't cheat yourself out of  getting your needed veggie serves for the day.  So try it the way it is presented before adding onions etc, it will be an entirely different taste, I promise you. And you will love it.  Then make your new recipe with modifications so you know the difference.  This was a sweet winter surprise I will be making every winter.  And sometimes I will modify it for variation, but not sure if it will actually be an improvement or not. This recipe is very excellent.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this for the first time today and just finished a bowl.  It was delicious.  I used a 20 oz package of hot turkey italian sausage. I used 2 cans of stewed tomatoes as suggested by other reviewers.  I used 2 cans of low sodium beef broth and 2 cups of salt free free chicen broth.  I added a can of kidney beans in addition to the great norther bean.  I also added about of cup of elbow macaroni during the last 9 minutes. I added zucchini and celery. Finally, I added a bag of frozen spinash.  My first reactiion was that the soup was a bit sweet and lacked salt.  I added some salt which tamed the sweetness. To reduce the sweetness in the future I think I'll use plain diced tomatoes and add italian seasons.   I'm looking forward to tomorrow because I think this is a soup that is even better left over.  A great soup that I will make often!

Made this to use up zucchini, chopped frozen spinach and some hot turkey sausage.  I cooked the links, then diced and browned them while chopping the rest of the veggies.  I only had chopped frozen spinach, so I nuked it for 3 minutes and added it and a tsp of italian seasoning with the zucchini.  After simmering it for 20 minutes or so, it was so good!  An easy flavorful keeper.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/324794.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup is amazing! I seldom cook with sausage and I have never made a sausage soup. It sounded a bit weird but had so many great reviews I risked it and doubled the recipe for a casual dinner for 12. I added 2 cans of kidney beans, 2 kinds of squash for color, used about 50% more sausage, half hot half mild, no added salt, low sodium broth and one chopped onion, a lot more pepper and a TBSP of Italian seasoning. I forgot to add the red wine someone suggested and next time will do that. On the side I offered cooked mini pasta and diced cooked potatoes for those who like their soup a bit heartier. If we weren't cutting out 'white food' I would have added one or the other to the soup. It was amazing and completely gone. Everyone loved it and I will be careful to make enough for leftovers next time. For this recipe, as quickly as it cooks, I think using a mandolin for the veggies gives you a much more evenly cooked result, especially for the squash and the carrots. Thank you SallyJun for a terrific recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wish I could give it 4.5 stars -- 4 seems too few, and 5 too many.  Though I think it could be tweaked to a 5-star level easily.

I made it exactly as written.  The recipe doesn't specify anything about the sausage, so I used Whole Foods spicy Italian sausage.  I think when I make it again, I might try a blend -- half spicy, half mild -- because it seemed to me that the spicy flavor dominated a little more than would be ideal.  That change alone would likely bump this to 5 stars.  

One other thing -- and it, too, might be a function of the specific sausage I used:  it seemed to me to be a tiny bit greasy when first I served it.  The next day I took the leftovers out and skimmed the excess fat off the top, and when I heated up the leftovers, that was no longer an issue.  Also, the flavors had mellowed a little the second day -- it seemed altogether better on day 2.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/294723.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
GREAT RECIPE!  I have made this a couple times now and love it.  I followed suggestions from other reviews and made the following changes: used hot italian sausage, 3 cloves of garlic, added 1 can of chicken broth, 1 small onion diced, 2 celery stalks diced, 1 can white kidney beans (drained and pureed), 1/2 cup uncooked orzo pasta and 1 tea crushed red pepper.  Brown sausage, celery, garlic and onion in dutch oven.  Add broth, tomatoes, carrots, crushed red pepper and pepper and simmer 1 hour uncovered.  Add pureed kidney beans and cook another half-hour.  Add zucchini and can of great northern beans and cook 15 minutes.  Add orzo and cook 5 min.  Add spinach and cook another 5 min.  Add extra water if too thick. Serve with shredded romano cheese on top.  The most important change is the addition of the orzo pasta.  It really made the soup delicious and filling.  Thanks for such a great recipe!

text:
This was delicious and so fast and easy to make! I got 4 fresh sausages from the butcher - 2 honey garlic, 2 hot (or whatever your fav is) and used a veggie broth.  I always take the meat out of  the casing (light slice down the center and rip the case off) chop into approx bite size pieces to brown.  I will add more broth next time as the next day when I reheated leftovers I found I wanted more juice for dipping!  I ate the soup with fresh french baguette mmmm.  I brought some to my parents and they loved it so much they went out and bought the ingredients to make it the next day! I'm here updating to say I add more than 4 sausages, more like 6...my guy loves the meat the most (surprise surprise)  Thanks you so much...healthy and amazing!

text:
EXCELLENT! This is my most favorite soup...to eat and make.  The only changes I made were to add 3 cloves of garlic instead of one, 6 cups of beef broth instead of two cans, two cans of great northern beans instead, I leave out the spinach, and I add 3/4 cup of orzo.  I don't add any salt at all because this recipe does not need it.  All my company I have served it to loves it and it is the favorite soup in this house for my husband and me.

text:
Sorry I didn't think this was that good. I made some changes & I now don't rate anything high that needed changes. I used a can of green beans instead of tomatoes, cabbage instead of spinache & added 1 chopped onion, 1 C. ditalini pasta & 1 extra can of beef broth. It tasted ok the day I made it, the sausage gives it all the flavor. The next day, the beans, zucchini & green beans were mushy. If you make this leave out the zucchini, you won't miss it. My husband said this had too much of a vegetable taste, not that he doesn't like vegetables but as in there were just too many. Sorry.

text:
OUTSTANDING SOUP!  YOU HAVE GOT TO GIVE THIS A TRY.  Tastes like it took you all day & yet it's ready in 30 mins.  We served this at a party of 50 people recently & it was such a hit.  I've made it 3 times since.  The flavors are wonderful together & the vegetables really make it very refreshing.  It's not a heavy soup like you would think.  I added small pasta (ditalini) during the last 10 mins or so (before the spinach) & it was a great addition.  Don't pass this one by!  It's a keeper.

Very good flavor!  Suggestion...don't add all of the zucchini, pasta or spinach to the original batch.  If you have leftovers they will be very mushy when reheated.  Add only enough per meal so that they are firm each time.

text:
I saved this recipe 2 years ago and finally made it last night.  OMG, why did it take me so long!   Awesomely delicious!  I did use a little diced onion, increased garlic, used half hot Italian and half chicken Italian and topped it with a little grated Parmesan.  I also added another can of beans to make it super substantial.  I can see using garbanzos in the future.  The combined ingredients provided plenty of salt so I did not need to add any more.  My husband is a gourmet cook, and he said this is a "keeper", which is high praise from him indeed!
1/8/20 UPDATE..For non red meat eaters, make this using chicken/turkey Italians and chicken broth.   The result is equally delicious!  I triple the  garlic and add onion to the saute also. I prefer using Muir Glen fire roasted tomatoes , NOT stewed.   Love this soup!

text:
Great recipe! Had to make a few substitutions based on what I had on hand. Used butter beans, added 2 squash cubed instead of zucchini, added about 1/3 cup of elbow noodles, a potato peeled and cubed and an extra can of diced Italian tomatoes and finally I only had 2 cans of broth so I added beef bullion granules and 2 cans of water to add enough liquid for all the starches. Did not add salt because of bullion. Super simple and delicious and a good use of veggies!! Loved it and will make again! Thanks!

text:
The recipe doesn't state type of sausage. I used cut up links and browned them with 4 cloves of garlic.  I substituted one can beef broth with vegetable broth and used about 2 cups carrots. The store did not carry canned "Northern beans" so I used white kidney beans. A 10oz bag of spinach is more than 2 cups but I probably could have put it all in. Will definitely make this again!  Served with garlic cheesy bread made from sub rolls. I love making soups; when my husband goes back for seconds, you know it's good!

So happy to have found this recipe! I have no doubt that this is perfect as it is but I added a tiny bit of leftover potatoes, onions, celery, and some italian seasonings. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7284585.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very hearty and filling soup! Based upon previous recommendations, I browned the sausage in another pan then drained it, added an extra cup of (low-sodium) beef broth, 1/2 cup of orzo (pasta) and used fresh baby spinach, which worked out rather well! NOTE: If you like your veggies a little on the firmer side, remember to allow the pasta time to cook as the soup simmers! I live overseas and often have to rig a recipe because I cannot find ingredients, but this one was no problem at all! Nearly all of its ingredients are staples of well-stocked pantries and fridges! Note: Rated 4 stars because the flavor of the sausage was a little overpowering for the dish and I think this recipe would benefit from additional herbs (rather than spiced tomatoes), such as basil, oregano and thyme, if the chef has the time and inclination.

text:
Awesome recipe. I know it's wrong to change the recipe then rate it, so let me say I've tried it as written and it it wonderful. So now let me tell you my changes. First off, this soup is so good I doubled it so my additions are for twice as much. Trust me, it's that good. I used 1 lb. hot and 1 lb. mild sausage casings removed. And 1 small diced red onion when browning the sausage with the garlic. I upped the garlic to 3 cloves. 5 cans of beef broth, 3 cans of tomatoes, 3 carrots dided, 4 yellow squash diced, 4 zuchinni diced, 3 cans of northern white beans. 3 bags of fresh baby spinach, and 1 bag of frozen white corn added at the end. I honestly think this is "THE" best soup I've had from this site. I have tried many and enjoyed many but this is my new favorite. Thanks to SallyJun. Killer soup.

This is the most delicious soup I've ever tasted. I am only 15 years old and I am not an expert in cooking. I did it by myself and the soup was wonderful and all my family members loved it. Some modifications: Brown the sausages not with oil but with butter and add some mushrooms and 1/2 chopped potato (to reduce the salt). Do not use can broth but make it by yourself. Boil any kind of meat(e.x chicken) in water and the broth is ready.

That was my first review so . . .

Whatever the recipe was: How Americans say: YUM!

text:
This is now officially one of my favorite soups.
I can't wait to make it on a cold winter night.
I'm a garlic lover, so I used 4 cloves, plus I added one large chopped Spanish onion, a handful of chopped fresh parsley thrown in with the spinach, fresh tomatoes instead of canned (nothing like fresh tomatoes in a soup!), and a few shakes of Italian seasoning. 
If you love a chunky, stick-to-your-ribs soup with tons of flavor and texture, this is for you!
DO NOT forget to pick up a fresh loaf of your favorite bread, because this soup practically begs for a good, old-fashioned Italian sopping up of the juices! Fantastic! Thank you!

Yummy!  Excellent and easy to make!  I read some of the other reviews and 1) took sausage out of casing, 2) added chopped onion with the garlic while browning sausage, 3) added 1/2 cup orzo, and 4) added two cups of water (I think it would have been too salty without the water. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family loved this recipe!  I did make some adjustments based on other recommendations.  I doubled the recipe, using half sweet and half hot Italian sausage. I added an onion, chopped, which I sauteed with the garlic.  I put the sausage, sauteed veggies, carrots, broth and tomatoes into a large crock pot and cooked on high for about 4 hours.  I added the beans for the last hour or so.  Then I cooked 2 lb. cheese tortellini and added it at the end.  I omitted the zucchini and spinach.  I also added some Tony Chatcheries Creole seasoning instead of salt, which gave it a little spicy zest.  My version was quite a bit different from the original, but was absolutely delicious.  The broth itself is outstanding!

text:
This soup was very hearty, and tasty. I did make a few changes, such as using 2 extra cups broth, using 1/2 turkey sausage (pork sausage is just too fatty), and 1/2 cubed chicken breast, and adding 1 1/4 cup mini shell pasta with the beans and zucchini. I also added about 30 min. to the cooking time. All in all, however, I enjoyed this recipe very much, would reccomend it, and intend on making it again in the future.

I also use half sweet sausage and half hot sausage, and use butternut squash instead of zucchini. The butternut is a nice addition to the contrast of sweet/savory in this soup. And lots of spinach as it withers away!

I tweaked the recipe by adding chopped onions and celery.  I softened the vegetables in the fat rendered from browning the sausage.  Added an additional can of diced tomatoes, a tablespoon of dried Italian herbs and a bay leaf.  Increased the stock to 32oz.  I left out the salt since the canned beans were not rinsed and drain.  The soup was wonderful.  My husband said it was the best soup he had tasted in a long time.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an extremely delicious and easy soup - one you can make on a weeknight!

I always make a new recipe exactly as written the first time, as a baseline. I don't play with it until I've seen what the original is like.

My only difference with this recipe is that I doubled the ingredients so I could freeze it (I read that it freezes well). I doubled everything, but thought it needed a third can (instead of two) of Italian recipe stewed tomatoes, and that made all the difference. Next time I'm going to try Rotel to see what happens.

I also think this soup benefits greatly from a longer cooking time if you can do it, because the flavors got more depth after 45 minutes uncovered. Just don't add the spinach until the last five minutes, because that must "cook" in the already hot soup with the lid on.

I will be making this recipe again and again for sure!!!

text:
This soup is tasty, quick and easy. I was looking for gluten free and hearty for my family. I doubled the recipe using J-ville mild Italian sausage and J-ville Hot Italian sausage. Just slice the casing to remove it and break meat into chunks in stock pot. Added a diced yellow onion. I skipped the garlic since the  stewed tomoatoes already have Italian seasoning in it. Used frozen spinach instead of fresh. Only thing I would do different is try to drain some of the grease after cooking meat before adding other ingredients.  Will make again.

text:
I love this.  We have probably made this at least 3 or 4 times.  2 times in the past couple weeks, it's so delicious!  It feeds us both a bowl for about 3 days (maybe 4).  The only thing we add is a whole onion, sliced, when adding the beans and zucchini.  We also use 2 packs of frozen spinach and throw in a handful (a little more than a cup) of shell (conchiglie) noodles that have already been cooked at the end with the spinach.  Excellent, excellent, excellent.  So fun to make and you could really put anything in it.  The beef broth/italian tomato soup base is outstanding alone.

city:

country:

text:
Okay, I'm not stupid. I followed this recipe very closely. I only added some of the other suggestions like oregano and doubling up on the beef broth. But i'm confused, I cooked the packaged italian sausage, this recipe says nothing about cutting it up (since mine was in links) I'm guessing it was supposed to cook it like ground beef. Anyway, I cooked it in the garlic, then cut up the italian sausage into bite sized pieces. Put in 2 cans of tomatoes, no carrots, 2 cans of northern beans, no zucchini, and let it simmer for 15 minutes. I also added two small yellow potatoes (cubed) which took A LOT longer to cook,(i think this is when it started to thicken) and then separately cooked a cup of pasta, drained and rinsed and then added. Mind you, if this is not eaten immediately, it turns into a big pot of mush!!

Outstanding!!  I couldn't beleive how simple and how delicious this soup was.  My husband raved about it and even my 11 year old said it was good.  I didn't add the zuccini because they didnt look good this time of year.  I bought the great northern beans that were not seasoned and I added 2 cans of regular beef broth. I simply served this with garlic bread.  I will be making this again for sure!

My husband keeps requesting this. I used hot turkey sausage. I made some changes based on reviews: 
- Subbed beef stock for broth and doubled it.
- Added meet or cheese tortellini instead of the beans.
- Added more carrots and an onion.
- Added a can of Rotel with the tomatoes
- Added some chipolte chili powder for a smokey flavor.
This is definitely company food!

Excellent soup and easy to make.  Ingredients were somewhat unclear as to what type of Italian Sausage to use.  As a result and act of faith that it was going to be super yummy I doubled the recipe and mixed both bulk mild italian as well as hot italian which I took out of the casings before cooking.  The combo of both provided a spicy yet not-too-hot flavor.  I also more than doubled the garlic but made no other changes.  Excellent recipe!  Could easily add some other things in like macaroni or sliced potato too but why mess with something that is so good to start with?!  Thanks!

Mmmm! I changed some things (soups are great b/c they're so easy to mix up and change without messing them up). I used kale greens instead of spinach (regular kale would work too). I used both chicken and beef broth and used 3 cans total. I added potatoes, carrots, mushrooms and some minced, fresh sage (b/c I had it laying around). I also threw in half an onion with the garlic/sausage (because I can't make soup w/o onion!). As you can see, I added a lot to the soup, hence the extra broth. Also, I used venison sausage!!! Yum yum yum, and healthy too!

text:
Absolutely delicious!!!  I removed the sausage from its casing and browned it.  Completely forgot to pick up beans at the store, so I didn't add them, but I didn't miss them, either.  Added some dittalini pasta (precooked so it didn't absorb too much of the broth) at the end with the spinach.  Served with some freshly grated parm cheese on top, and crusty Italian bread.  Will be making this again and again!!

A good soup to have when you're sick or on a cold day.  I made couple of changes (which also included another reviewer's recommendations):

A. Italian sweet sausages were used, casing was taken off.

B. I used Cannellini beans instead.

C. 2 cans of Italian style stewed tomatoes.

D. 1 onion, sliced.

E. 1 jalapeno (chopped).

text:
Very tasty! I drained the fat after I browned the sausage before adding the other ingredients. I used a 32 oz container of beef sirloin broth instead of the 2 14 oz cans. Because I had extra broth, I added 1 1/2 c. of brown rice elbow pasta. Cooked the pasta separately & added it to the soup about a minute before I served it.  My husband is not a big carrot & zuchinni fan so I chopped them into small cubes.  Put some shredded parmesan cheese on top of each serving after I put it in the bowl.  My husband had two bowls of it, he loved it so much. Thanks Sallyjun, definitely a keeper!

text:
This soup had such a great aroma to it.  I changed the recipe a little cause I had to use what I had on hand.  I think it came out fantastic.  Especially if you are a garlic lover.  Here are my changes:  I used a package of precooked garlic chicken sausage.  I just removed the skin and cut into 1/4 inch pieces.  I used chicken broth instead of beef and I used two cans Italian-style stewed tomatoes.  I did not add the salt as I think the chicken broth has plenty in it.  I added a diced onion, basil and oregano.  Serve it with crusty bread and grated parmesan cheese.  YUM!

text:
Awesome simple yummy and hearty soup. Perfect for winter. I used sweet sausages I added more garlic. I also added raw orzo to mine and it turned out fantastic. Be careful adding raw orzo because it will absorb a lot of the broth. Either add more broth or cook your orzo in its own pot before adding it to the soup.

This was fabulous. I made it as written, except I didn't add salt (it didn't need it at all). I used 2 mild and 2 hot Italian sausages. I think I might have cooked the sausage a bit too long because it was slightly too chewy, but everything else was fantastic. Oh, the cooking time took a lot longer for the carrots. I waited until they were done before I added the baby spinach leaves.

SAINTPAULIA23

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup was excellent! I made a few changes based on other recommendations and personal preference.  I first browned the sausage with a bit of EVO in a large pot, then removed the meat and sauteed onion, celery and carrots. Instead of canned tomatoes, I used homegrown orange ones which are slightly sweeter and a bit less acidic and added them in with the homegrown zuke and liquid to cook a bit longer. I used my own blend of italian seasoning, including a bay leaf which was extracted before serving. I also added white wine and substituded homemade roasted garlic for garlic cloves. I did not add the liquid from the beans, but did rinse them and tossed in a few handfuls of macaroni as they were on hand. Orzo or other italian soup pastas would work just fine, but it thickened up the soup and there was no need for the bean liquid. I garnished with fresh grated parm and it was absolutely delicious!

text:
The best!!

Changed I made:

chicken broth instead of the beef, sauted 1 chopped onion and celery.  Used white kidney beans, fresh baby spinach 1/4 cup small pasta soup noodles.

Someimes, I make mini meatball with ground pork, ground beef, 1 egg, bread crumbs and parsley. I roast the meatballs and throw them in the soup.

Be careful not add too many meatball...you don't want a super thick soup.

It is so good!

text:
Nutritious and hearty. A great soup to herald the fall. I used chicken sausages, added a diced onion, a sweet potato for the carrots (but diced in small cubes for quick cooking), leftover al dente pasta, skipped the zucchini, and added a heaping teaspoon of italian seasoning, a tsp of Worchestershire sauce, and a tsp of A1 Black Peppercorn. That last addition was a whim and was so good! That small amount added heat and a new dimension. Just if you have any on hand. This is comfort food express and easily customized to accommodate leftovers!

I'm keeping this recipe forever.  It came out fantastic.... except next time i may skip the spinach because i overboiled it and it turned stringy so i tried to fish as much out as possible.  Thats a knock on my own bad cooking technique not the recipe though.

I added orzo pasta and doubled certain parts of the recipe (stock & sausage+ add more veggies) to fill the stock pot so i have enough to freeze for later.  I used a couple of types of beans (cannolini, northern beans and chick peas) to mix it up a bit.  Wonderful recipe.

country:
None
text:
yum yum yum! A hearty, delicious soup that you can feel good about eating. I made a few changes that came out absolutely perfect. I heeded others advice and added an additional 2 cups of broth. I also took the sausage out of its casing and made little meatballs as another cook suggested...what a great idea! Being a potato lover, I cut two white potatoes into eighths, with the skin on and tossed them in with the broth. I also used Cannellini Beans instead. Lastly, I added some fresh parsley and an additional clove of garlic.  I let the soup simmer for about 1 hour and a half on low, stirring occasionally. Make this soup...you will not regret it! YUM.

userID:
2602879
Display Name:
holly65584

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is very, very good and quite versatile. Let me get something out of the way that I disagreed with.... the recipe says to use the liquid with the beans, but I ALWAYS RINSE THE BEANS.... I can't imagine pouring that junk into my fresh, homemade soup!

I like to saute most of my ingredients before I put them in the soup (except tomato). 

I only made a small batch using leftover sausage and peppers.  To begin, I made a broth of two cups of Wylers granules (bullion), but generally I enjoy Emeril's beef stock, which is outstanding... much better than beef broth, powered or canned. 

In a saucepan I combined to lightly simmer the leftover sausage and peppers with the beef broth, fresh salt and pepper, 2 fresh basil leaves and about 2/3 can of plain diced tomatoes. 

Meanwhile, I chopped and sauteed celery, green onion and yellow squash for about ten minutes. I rinsed the navy beans and    combined it all together.

It was tasty and delicious and I'll make it again. I didn't have any spinach, but I would definitely like to try that next time.

I would also enjoy trying it over Ditalini pasta, which holds up well with soup.

Enjoy!

text:
This recipe wasn't as good as I had expected - it was just 'OK' for me.  I made the soup as is and thought the flavor was 'OK.' (as always, I use the best quality ingredients I can find at Whole Foods).  I didn't drain the grease from the sausage, and I am glad I did so because it helped with the flavor.  I think for this recipe to be a really good "Italian" sausage soup, it has to have the Italian trinity for soups (onion, carrots, and celery).

text:
Tuscan Soup on this site had been my favorite but this replaces it (although I will continue to make both!).  I used chicken broth instead of beef but that is my preference when I make soup with sausage.  Didn't have stewed tomatoes so used canned diced tomoatoes already seasoned with basil, garlic and oregano.  Omitted the zucchini since we don't care for it.  Made this a day ahead of time so I used another reviewers suggestion and added the canned beans and spinach when I was reheating it so they wouldn't get too soggy.  Really a quick, simple soup to make - it does get better and better as it sits!!!

This is a very unique and delicious soup!  Our family (both kids included) really liked it.  I've made this recipe several times since finding it here last year.  Depending on what you're in the mood for heat-wise, add HOT Italian sausage to clear your sinuses! city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was wonderful! I did make a few changes though. I used sweet turkey sausage, 4 cups of beef broth, one can of diced tomato's and one can of tomato sauce, northern beans which I did drain because they are just too slimy for me undrained, no zucchini and definitely no spinach. I also added a half teaspoon of garlic powder, onion powder, basil and about a half tablespoon of sugar to give it a little sweetness. Oh...and also a pinch of cayene for a little bit of heat. Just before serving I added about a 1/8 of a cooked cup of elbow macaroni to each day then topped with parmasan cheese and it was wonderful. I will definitely be making this one again! Thank you Karen :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was great, and my hubby loved it too--even the broth, which is unusual for him. I read a few reviews, and made the following changes:
* used two or three cloves garlic
* Added one diced potato at the same time as the carrots
* Skipped the salt
* Used a bag of frozen spinach instead of fresh, but microwaved it per the instructions on the bag, and added it in the last five minutes 
* cooked up 1 cup of ditalini pasta separately, and added it in the last five minutes
* Used a can of diced (instead of stewed) Italian tomatoes
* I only had one can of beef broth, so replaced one with 2 cups hot water and two cubes beef bouillon 
* added a can of chicken broth too

It was great, and it made a lot (perhaps due to my modifications). I'm looking forward to leftovers tomorrow!

Great recipe!

This is truly excellent!  I have never made a soup without onions and celery so I added those - broke up the stewed tomatoes a bit cause they were large, added extra garlic, and some fresh thyme, oregano &  parsley from our garden, a splash of worchestershire, some onion powder to add depth and a bit more broth - this was heart warming, excellent!  I didn't season with salt & pepper til more towards the end.  I also used baby spinach after i removed from heat.  My husband loved it too with crusty french baguette.  This is a keeper!

text:
A friend introduced me to this recipe a few years ago, and I've made it a dozen times, since. A definite keeper. I always double the recipe but quadruple the carrots, zucchini and beans. Something else I recommend is instead of adding the spinach to the soup pot, I put fresh baby spinach leaves in each serving bowl, and ladle the hot soup on top. This way, everyone gets super-fresh, perfectly wilted spinach, especially the next day.

None
text:
Of all the recipes that I have made from this site this one truly lived up to it's rave reviews. My family devoured it! So easy to make and so good. I did double the recipe and I did make a few minor changes based on other reviewer's suggestions. I added a large chopped onion, extra garlic, an extra 2 cups of beef broth, 12oz of orzo and the saugage I used was 1/2 hot and 1/2 sweet.  For my daughter who who does not want to "waste" her points on pasta I put her portion of the soup in another pot and added chopped cauliflower and chunks of mushrooms.  The cauliflower was her "pasta" and it absorbed the flavors beautifully.  While still eating the soup my family was asking me when I was going to make it again.  I guess that says it all!

ok this was REALLY good! I did have to tweak the recipe to go along with what I had on hand.... so goes, sauted onion, garlic and celery along with sweet Italian sausage. Used about 1/2 a container of beef broth. Used fresh spinach and 1 can of diced tomatoes. Let it simmer till the biscuits were done.

text:
First time making this tonight. I left out the beans (they don't like me). I did add a chopped onion and cooked macaroni pasta. Used low sodium and no MSG beef broth. Everything else besides the salt was the same. Before adding the 3 cups of cooked macaroni, it seems like there wasn't enough broth. But I ended up adding macaroni instead. That soaked up all the broth. After it was made, I added a sprinkle of parmesan cheese. It was a nice and hearty so called soup. My husband and I liked it, however my son wouldn't touch it. He didn't like the look nor the veggies. If I do make this next time, more broth, less pasta.

text:
Wonderful recipe! This soup tastes better the second day. I change a few things, add sauteed onion, and a can of black beans with the Northern beans, and turkey breakfast sausage. I also omit the zucchini since my husband does not like it. I never measure the spinach and let it wilt in the soup. I also top this soup with some shredded Monterrey Jack cheese to serve and it melts and makes for a delicious topping. This is our favorite soup!

userID:

Display Name:
Illidanas
isPro:

2

46

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7225713.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used this recipe more as a building block for my own soup there was so many changes. I'm sure this soup is good as it stands, but the inspiration it gave me made it the final product very delicious. I added one large potato, diced and cooked it in olive oil for about ten minutes with sausage (not ground, summer/kielbasi style) that was also diced. While that was cooking I made the beef broth, added the garlic, some basil, ground coriander, oregano and black pepper. Once the seasonings were added I cut up the stewed tomato's and put them in, followed by the sausage and potato's. Cooked at a slight boil covered for about an hour, added the beans and spinach, cooked for another 15-20 minutes and served it with bread. It, was, amazing and my company loved it. Will definitely make again.

text:
Awesome! Although I did change it up a bit. I used a bit of butter to saut green onion, celery, garlic and mushrooms then added mild Italian sausage and browned it in the same pan. Next I added a can of diced tomatoes, a tablespoon of tomato paste, a drained can of white beans, carrots, zucchini, a bag of fresh spinach and a large carton of low sodium chicken broth. Seasoned with black pepper and a few red peppers flakes and let it cook until veggies were tender. Before serving I added pasta and let it cook. Yummy!

text:
The most finicky bunch of eaters (my family) loved this soup! I have been told to put it into the rotation, and to make it exactly the same way.  I modified two things: I used 2 hot and 3 sweet italian sausages as others suggested. Also,  I degreased the sausages after frying them  (put them into a paper towel lined sieve) and I did not add any salt or pepper. Other than that, I followed the recipe as printed. 

After working all day its a real treat to make a soup this good in under one hour.  Add a nice stick of French bread or the like and viola! - dinner is served!

text:
This was delicious! Very easy to make.  Matter of fact, I am eating it now. I made some slight changes to the recipe. I added an onion, 2 cans of Italian style stewed tomatoes, and I use 32 ounces of low sodium beef broth. I had some squash in the refrigerator and I threw that in as well. I didn't have any spinach, but had Swiss Chard, so I used that instead. I know some people included rice or pasta, but I am watching my carbs. I also did't add salt or include the juice from the beans since I am watching my sodium. At the end it tasted great with the Swiss Chard and I added a little bit of grated Parmesan cheese.

One of the easiest and tastiest soups I've ever made. The few changes I made were: sauteed 1 diced onion with the garlic and sausage; added extra garlic; added 1/2 tsp Italian Seasonings; added an extra can of broth; and added 1/4 cup of dried orzo 10 min before soup was done. Delish and so pretty.

text:
This is a yummy soup.  I generally cook the sausage without the garlic and then rinse it a little and omit the salt so it isn't too salty - salt can be added at the table if necessary.  After I rinse the sausage I add the garlic & carrots (I also add onion and celery) and let that cook for a bit before adding the broth and tomatoes.  I also like to serve it with about a tablespoon of fresh grated Parmesan cheese.  YUM!

WhiGru

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe with a few changes based on preference and items on hand and it was AWESOME. I read some reviews and adjusted accordingly.
-1lb Hot italian sausage
-2 cloves garlic
-1 med. sweet onion
-1 big baking potato, cubed
-2 cans diced tomatoes (1 petite, 1 italian flavored)
-24ish oz beef broth
-1cup julienned carrots
-wilted in about 2cups frozen spinach after removing from heat

I did this all in the dutch oven and subbed the potato because my husband does not like beans, and left out the zucchini because I had forgotten to buy some. Other than that, this was a WONDERFUL soup and didnt require any additional seasoning (besides some pepper) because the sausage did that all on it's own. I toasted up some ciabatta bread to go with it but it was perfect all on it's own. For my daughters, I added some pre-made wheat elbows to give it more substance, and I bet adding some sort of pasta in it would be good too. definitely a make-again!

text:
I've been making this soup since seeing it in the allrecipes cookbook back in 2005. I usually double the recipe because everyone in my family LOVES this soup, plus I want plenty of leftovers. I never have measured the spinach when I make it - I always just use 2 bags (since I double the recipe) of fresh baby spinach. It seems like a lot but it's soooooo good! I'll serve this with some kind of hard roll, so you can get up all the juice from this delicious soup! It's not my recipe, but my family considers it one of my soup recipes since I make it so much! Definitely recommend it to EVERYONE!!!

text:
I have made this recipe many times and love it. This recipe really is great all by itself without any changes, but I like to make just a couple modifications to make it more kid friendly. I do add (already cooked) bow tie pasta and sprinkle the filled bowls with Parmesan so it is more appealing for my kids.  With the addition of the pasta, I add a few more ounces of beef broth. Even though I cook the pasta prior to adding it to the soup, I'm sure it still sucks up some of the broth.  Also, I prefer pinto beans in general over Northern beans, so I do substitute those.

Made this yesterday.  I was amazed that the simple ingredients came together to form such a beautiful, tasty soup.  I only added 1 cup of couscous to the original recipe to fill in. I was hoping to have a bowl for breakfast today, but they wiped it out last night.  Thank you for the easy, great soup recipe!

I made this this morning for two good friends who are not feeling well, for lunch on a cold day and for them to freeze the leftovers.  Served with crusty baguette and assorted cheeses.  Maybe it was the reheating or the company but it was very, very good.  I will make it again soon for just us.  By popular request I will increase the baby spinach to 1 1/2 bags, already doubled the garlic.  Luckily one of our local stores carries bulk mild sausage so I won't have to strip it out of the casings.  One of the reasons for winter is great soups like this!

country:
None
text:
Very tasty & so comforting on a chilly evening! Made pretty close to directions: Used 2/3 sweet & 1/3 hot Italian sausage, subbed chayote for zucchini & orzo for beans (only cuz they were on hand) & sauteed 1/2 chopped onion w/ the sausage & garlic, which I then drained all the grease from. NO NEED to add salt & pepper due to the sausage. Also, I felt it needed more liquid & added 2 cans chicken broth (again, that's what I had & btw, all broths were low sodium). So even though I didn't follow the recipe exactly believe the base of it warrents 5 stars. With crusty french bread to sop up all the yummy broth this pot of soup easily fed 8.

text:
Very easy to make--Soup broth (?) has a good flavor. I used the ground sweet italian sausage breaking it down somewhat into tiny pieces, chopped the stewed tomatoes up until almost a puree and added to the broth, drained the beans and substituted 1/2 cup water in its place. Added 'acini de pepe' noodles (tiny dots) for the 'Italian' in me -- next time I make, I want to add some peas. Perfect on a spur-of-the-moment winter night.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love these kinds of recipes because they allow you to mold things to your liking.  I had leftover sausage from making a pizza, so this was perfect.  If you like it spicy go for hot sausage but I think sweet Italian sausage is so much better.  Also, I use buillon instead of broth so I just add equivalent amounts of water and cubes, I had no Italian style tomatoes so I used regular but next time I will probably add oregano and basil to the soup to make up for it, used bell pepper instead of zucchini since its what I had on hand and frozen spinach instead of fresh.  As long as you use appropriate amounts of liquid, you can do whatever you want with these and it will be wonderful. That's the beauty of these.  Small pasta would probably be great with this too.  Wonderful soup, a definite keeper and a good base for all kinds of new ideas!

text:
Delicious!  My family loves soup, and I was looking for something new.  I don't think I would have picked this to make based on the recipe--it sounds a little odd.  But, after reading the raving reviews, I HAD to try it, and we loved it!  I have made it twice, once with italian sausage, and once w/turkey sausage & added italian seasoning.  Both were excellent.  I used 3-4 cans chicken broth instead of beef, 1/2 package frozen spinach instead of fresh, and extra garlic.  Other than that, I followed the recipe.  Oh, I also put some small pasta in at the end, but found it got mushy after sitting-- so the second time I cooked dilantini separately, and added it to each bowl of soup--that way even leftovers were perfect!  Yum!

text:
This is a great basic recipe that can be customized with whatever you have on hand. I made it with a mix of hot & sweet Italian sausage that I removed from the casings and browned. I used black beans because that's what I had. I made this more like a "stoup" -- a little thicker than a soup, thinner than a stew -- and mixed in a bag of Success brown rice just before serving. Family loved it!

AMAZING!!! One reviewer remarked that this recipe has alot of "wiggle room"...perfectly put. My amendments were: ground pork in place of sausage, used up the left over spaghetti sauce, added mushrooms, pinto beans, sweet red peppers, diced onions, and whole wheat pasta. text:
This was really good! I had some leftover sweet italian sausages & was looking for a diffrent way to use them up then the way we always have them. I will admit I was a little hesitant making this as its not at all something I would normally make but I've been in the soup mode lately since its getting chilly out & with all the good reviews I had to try it out. I changed the recipe around a bit based on other reviewers suggestions & my own personal taste. I used 2 can's of chicken broth because thats what I had on hand. I also added to equal amounts of water to cut the salt down. I also left the added salt out it didn't need it. I used 3 cloves of garlic cause I love it!! And instead of zuccini & spinach I used mushrooms & potatoes. It was delish! I had it again for lunch today & it had even more flavor today!! Great easy & quick soup to throw together for a weeknight meal :)

text:
I made this using only the ingredients stated in the recipe except I sprinkled grated Romano cheese on top of each bowl.  I did not measure any of the ingredients.  The soup is excellent as is with no changes needed.  I had a friend who loves to cook over for lunch and he asked for the recipe, first time ever.  I used low sodium beef broth, tomatoes, and I rinsed the beans.  I wanted to be able to control how much salt was in the soup.  Easy and Excellent!!!!  Im sending this recipe to my son, sister, brothers and my 81 year old dad.  They will love it too.  Enjoy!!!!

I really am not a fan of broth-based sopups although I will prepare them but this soup has completely changed my mind. It blows my mind how simple amd delicious it is. I used "Johnson's mild Italian sausage" and oh so yummy!!! With my changes this soup will feed many many people I have tons of leftovers in the fridge and also froze some. I think I'm going to try adding some kind of starch next time. text:
oh so good!!! If you want to make this lower fat without losing the flavor I suggest buying the turkey breakfast sausage and just adding a teaspoon of fennel seed to give it that italian sausage taste without the fat! If you like a little spice put 1/4 teaspoon of crushed red pepper. I also used frozen spinach. You can put fun shaped pasta with a little extra broth or water so they kids will not turn their nose up.

text:
This is the best soup I have ever had! It was really easy to make, too. I added a potato. I put the zucchini in with the other vegetables and then let it simmer as directed. Instead of the cans of beef broth, I just used 4 cups of water and 4 beef boulion squares. After 15 minutes, I added the beans and spinnach and covered for 5 minutes. Adding the zucchini early and skipping the additional 15 minute simmer did not make a difference in the soups taste. I will definetly be making this many times this winter! Thankyou!

OUTSTANDING.  I tend not to measure ingredients to closely when making something like soup but here are the things I did definitely based on other reviews: i used 5 hot sausages and 3 sweet which I sauteed with garlic and oil, I used 5 cans of chicken broth, a big can of diced tomatoes, celery, 2 cans of beans, no add'l salt, I forgot the spinach, ops, a bag of sweet corn.  I also cooked a box of Barilla Plus elbows which we added as we served the soup.  This soup is as good as all the reviewers say!  Thanks.

text:
Delicious. I would recommend draining the fat from the sausage and pan before proceeding with the rest of the recipe.  Without doing this I found the soup to be too greasy. Like others, I add a hearty, small-shaped pasta.  Cooking the pasta separately and adding it directly to your bowl, avoids making the soup too chunky as the pasta soaks up the broth.  I also use 4 cups of broth when using pasta.

This is such a great base recipe. So much can be done with it and it still comes out really good! I make this soup often during the winter.  I usually follow the suggestion of using 3 hot sausages and 2 mild ones but often times its just a matter of what I have in the house. Wonderful and perfect for a cold, Winter night!  Instead of stewed tomatoes, I added can of diced tomatoes with chili (medium hot). Instead of fresh spinach, used frozen. Instead of beef broth, used low sodium chicken broth. Instead of zucchini, I added small elbow macaroni. After cooking sausage, drained fat and dried off sausage with paper towel to soak up as much grease as possible. Topped off with a little freshly grated Padano Parmesan and Romano cheeses. This is a soup I will be making again and again.  Thanks Karen!

text:
This definetely is a hearty soup.  As always, I adjusted the recipe a bit.  I bought the beans but when I opened the can they smelled so horrible that I decided not to use them.  I doubled the zucchini, added 2 tbsp. of fresh basil and 1/2 cup of chopped onion.  My husband was so full off of one bowl that he didn't have room for seconds!  We will absolutely be making this again.

text:
Update: 12/5/15  I still make this 8 years later! I use 2 pkgs Alfresco brand Chicken Italian sausage (super low fat!) I also saute 1 medium yellow onion chopped with the sausage.  Amazingly good flavor considering the short cooking time! Threw in some shredded cabbage, chopped Kale & added zucchini last 10 mins. Added 1 can of chicken broth in addition to the beef broth. Kids used to love it!! They are gone, but they make it in their homes now! LOVE THIS!!!!

text:
Ok I changed this recipe a bit to suit the likes of my family.  I added some onion to the browning sausage.  Omitted the spinach simply because we didn't have it.  Changed the zuchini to mixed vegetables and some mushrooms because we are mushroom freaks.  I didn't have Italian tomatoes but I used regular diced tomatoes.  I also added some Italian seasoning.  This has quickly become a family favorite and my husband asks for it now almost weekly.  It takes no time at all to throw together and tastes like you've slaved all day.  It's rich and hearty and what more can I say....We love it.

This soup was wonderful. My husband asked if we could have the rest for the next night's dinner. The only substitution I used was original stewed tomatoes because I didn't have the Italian-style and then added some Italian seasoning. I also used an extra can of broth so I could add 1/2 cup of ditalini and still have enough broth as suggested earlier. And for those who thought it was too salty. Just use low-sodium beef broth. Mine wasn't salty at all. Thanks for the recipe, Karen.

text:
This soup was excellent....I used about 1 1/2lbs. of hot Italian sausage. I browned them and cut them into coin pieces and then added 2 cloves of garlic to the pan and sauteed briefly. I added the sausage to my crockpot with all the rest of the ingredients....(I used a box of frozen spinach, drained and squeezed dry). Cooked on low for about 7 hours. Very hearty and delish! Loved the spiciness of the hot sausage...served with crusty bread and a salad! Will become a winter favorite....and will try hot turkey sausage next time. Thanks!

THIS RECIPE WAS VERY GOOD, BUT IT LACKED THREE SIMPLE THINGS THAT I THINK MADE IT EXCEPTIONAL. FIRST I SAUTEED A FEW GREEN ONIONS ALONG WITH THE SAUSAGE AND GARLIC. JUST BEFORE ADDING THE REST OF INGREDIENTS I ADDED ABOUT 3/4 TSP WHOLE THYME AND ABOUT 1/2 TSP OREGANO. ALSO, IF YOU CAN FIND RAPPINI, USE IT IN PLACE OF SPINACH AND ADD IT IN WITH TOMATOES & CARROT. WHAT A MEAL WITH A BIG CHUNK OF GARLIC BREAD !!!

text:
Wow - best soup I've ever made!I cannot believe how much flavor is in this soup! The only changes I made are (1)used Butterball lean turkey/pork sausage, (2)added a few dashes of hot sauce (3)used lower sodium broth (4)for spinach, used about a handful of thawed frozen apinach from the bag and (5)cooked the whole thing (besides browning the sausage first) in the crockpot. A must keep recipe...

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is one of my favorite soups that have made over and over again for years.  I don't modify it much.  I have switched to using kale instead of spinach because the spinach breaks down too much if you have to reheat the soup.  Kale holds up better.  In autumn, I use fresh shelled Borlotti beans in it instead of canned.  I like it more like soup than stew so I use 2 32-ounce boxes of beef broth and it's still super hearty.  So delicious!

city:

country:
None
text:
I made this!  It was AWESOME.

I made a few adjustments because I didn't have the exact ingredients and honestly i love the way my version of this tastes.

I had a big package of italian sausage i needed to use so I ended up doubling the recipes.  Instead of beef broth i used chicken broth.  Instead of stewed tomatoes I did diced and probably a bit less than the recipe calls for.  I added some italian seasoning and chili pepper.  I didn't put in any salt and it was salty enough for me.

I also didn't add northern beans (I didn't have any) and used arugala instead of spinach.  The arugala gives it a great flavor but I would say if you don't like the bitter flavor of arugala to begin with, stick with the spinach.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This soup was very good, I do agree with another reviewer though that it is necessary to use low sodium beef broth, it ended up being pretty salty. I used mild Italian sausage, and doubled the broth, added 1/2 cup of orzo noodles, doubled the tomatoes and beans, added extra garlic and half of an onion when I cooked the sausage. This soup is extremely versatile, and I love that you can pretty much add anything to it and it will still turn out good. Next time I will probably use diced tomatoes because my bf and I arent a huge fan of big pieces of tomato. I kept the spirit of the soup the same and just ended up doubling the tomatoes, beans and garlic to make up for the extra broth I added to put in the orzo noodles. I think next time I might add some green/red peppers and some celery. It was very easy to make after a long day at work, and the leftovers were delicious!

Display Name:
Michelle

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup is my absolute favorite. My boyfriend always raves about it, and weve made it about 10 times over the past 2 months.  It is 5 stars exactly as written buthis also easy to customize.  I do recommend draining the sausage though before adding the next ingredients and my zucchini generally doesnt need to simmer 15 minutes.  I use 1/2 lb sweet Italian sausage and 1/2 lb spicy.  The soup is very hearty and not very brothy, so if Im in the mood for more broth I add an extra 2 cups or water with some beef bouillon depending on what I have on hand. I have also made with cheese tortellini instead of the beans and it was amazing! Sometimes I chop half an onion if I have one on hand, and I use more garlic if I have it.  I got a new Dutch oven for Christmas and the first thing I did was go buy the ingredients for this soup.  Ive even made it in the mini kitchen of a hotel when traveling for work because I couldnt stop thinking about it. I tell everyone about it, because its seriously so good.

text:
I've made this recipe more than 10x.  I use 16-18oz of spicy Italian saus.  Links or ground both work. If using links, take a knife, pierce the sausage casing and remove by peeling it off so it's easier to break up the link meat.  I would NOT recommend  using the suggested/Advertised Hillshire Farm Smoked Sausage that is listed in the Ingredients.
I've substituted potatoes for the beans  and added celery instead of zucchini. Either  way, this recipe is a keeper.

text:
To the sausage, I added:
one extra clove of garlic
1/2 of a small onion, diced

When I added the tomatoes, I also added:
a few sprigs of fresh thyme and rosemary (remove stems when soup is done cooking)
a parmesan rind

To serve, I added a couple of heaping tablespoons of cooked tubettini pasta to each bowl, mixed it in and then garnished with fresh grated parmesan cheese.
