1.20.19  I was a little short on the spinach, otherwise, followed the recipe to the letter.  My husband thought it was a little bland, but I think he was expecting the sausage to have more of a kick.  I used Johnsonville mild ground Italian sausage, so that may the reason for his comment.  To appease him, I did add some red pepper flakes and a healthy dose of Tabasco Sriracha., and admittedly, I then liked it better, too!  We were pleased with the way this turned out.  Easy enough to make for sure, and was the perfect soup for a cool winter day.

userID:
15932327
Display Name:
LadyJane
isPro:

madeRecipesCount:
14

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Based on highly liked reviews, I used the best of all advice the first time around: doubled the garlic, added a chopped onion to crumbled hot Italian sausage, used two cans of diced tomatoes, and 18 extra ounces of beef stock. Because I didnt have Italian style tomatoes (and I like fresh herbs), I added 1 tbsp fresh shredded basil, 2 Tbsp fresh parsley and sprinkles of dry oregano. Also two large zucchinis and the 1/2 c orzo. I agree...its a new staple!!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made a double batch as I wanted leftovers to have for lunch during the week. I used TJ's spicy Italian chicken sausage,  a box and a half of low sodium beef  broth, 1 can diced tomato, 2 cans stewed tomato , 2 cans Northern beans and added a chopped yellow onion 6 cloves minced garlic. For seasoning I used crushed red pepper,  oregano and salt and pepper  to taste. For the fresh veggies, I used about a cup chopped carrots (less than what is called for but I don't like a lot of carrots in my soup) 3 cubed small zucchini and a standard bag of baby spinach. I tried to serve all of the spinach in the supper portions and plan to have more spinach on hand to add to the hot lunch portions. It wilts really fast and gets lost, so I assume it won't reheat well. I serves with a handful of cooked cheese tortellini in the bottom of each bowl. I will make it again, maybe with a little tomato paste to thicken it up.

text:
While no one mentioned, skim off oil derived from sausage periodically, during simmering process. Didnt add any salt till very end, waiting to see how much broth and sausage would add. I had some homemade uncooked linguine, which I cut up into pieces and added same time as zucchini. After the first time you make this dish, youll feel comfortable modifying to your own taste, and be creative adding different ingredients.

text:
Part way through my review on my phone, somehow I submitted before I was done. Here's what I did: Pulsed one large onion in food processor (FP.). Removed casing from a package of Johnsonville brats. In a large pot break up sausage into chunks. Add chopped onions and saute until meat is done. Pulse spinach leaves ( half of a large Costco container. Took three batches in Cuisinart - it wouldn't pulse if too full. Probably 6 cups chopped. Add to the meat. Pulse a bunch of celery, probably 3 cups pulsed. Add to meat. Pour in one large can (32 oz?) of crushed tomatoes. Add 32 oz of water -or so. Add one beef and one chicken bouillon- mrs. knife - pretty big cubs - makes 2 cups broth each.Add Italian seasoning. 1-2 Tablespoons? Add sugar. 2-4Tablespoons? Add garlic salt a 1 tablespoon? Taste. Add red wine, about a cup. Add one csn iofwhite beans. 16 oz? But more would be fine. It was good with biggish chunks of sausage. Let simmer for an hour or so. It's better the longer it sits. I turned off heat and let it start to cool then ate it. Delicious!

text:
4 stars because I made adjustments, but great base!  After reading lots of reviews...I did the following 1)  3 cans , low-sodium broth 2) 2 cans tomatoes 3) extra carrots - probably 1-1/3 cup 4) a few dashes italian seasoning 5) 1-2 dashes crushed red pepper 6) 1/2-2/3 cup pasta added in last 15 minutes  7) 1/4 C. White wine (not 7 1/4 cup :) that is just #7 I drank the rest) Ha Ha! 8) 2 pods garlic and 1 medium chopped onion 9)  Frozen instead of fresh spinach.  I served with cornbread, which I'm sure is not Italian in any sense of the word, but it was goooood!

This was very good. I added an onion before the garlic, and I used chicken broth instead of beef and green bean instead of zucchini. Was great for a cold weekend, and fairly inexpensive for a large double batch.

text:
Have made this several times.  Using bulk sausage gives you a taste of sausage in every spoonful, and using link sausage that's been cut into small pieces downplays the sausage taste just a bit.  Either way, it is scrumptious.  The terrific thing about homemade soup is that you can taste every individual ingredient, and also tweak the salt and other spices to your own taste.  I had never had this kind of soup before, and now it's one of my very favorites.   Great recipe!!

text:
So, true story... I didn't know I was making this soup until it was almost done.  I mean, I looked at the ingredients, bought everything I would need, looked at my rating from the "last time" and started cooking.  Well, I thought I was making Italian Tortellini Soup, and when I clicked back and forth between my last rating and the recipe, it finally occurred to me, "what am I making?"  I panicked for a second when I thought I wasn't following any recipe at all!  Nonetheless, I finished cooking and tried the soup.  For now I'm going to give it three stars, because I'm sure I messed something up along the way.  As far as I know, I  cooked the recipe as called for, but omitted the beans (since I didn't recall using beans the "previous" time I had cooked this), and added an 8oz can of tomato sauce.  I used hot Italian sausage and frozen spinach.  I also added just a little celery.  I containered and froze most of what I made and kept a little for lunch tomorrow.  We'll see how it heats up after sitting for a day.  For now, I'll say it was ok but I'm not sure I'll make it again.

text:
One star taken away because it was very salty. I made this soup exactly as written. I used turkey Italian sausage and dry beans, so that was the only difference.  I didn't add the liquid from the canned beans because I didn't have any.  .  I didn't buy salt-free beef broth or salt free tomatoes, but I will the next time.  I would not change a thing. My husband just raved about it.  Filling and fairly nutritious.  If I use salt-free broth the next time, I may had some bay leaf, oregano or even some fennel seeds for flavor.  I'd rather  season it that way instead of with tons of salt.....and I like salt.

Gloria

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe!  Just some suggestions, all optional, to those who want to add them.  Great Northern beans are a great choice, but change them up with Cannellini (White Kidney Beans),  or Garbanzo.  I also added 1 Cup sliced celery, as well as 1 small diced onion, and 1 Cup of sliced fresh mushrooms.  I saute'ed the the onions and mushrooms when the sausage was almost done cooking, cooked it for an additional 5 min, then added the garlic during the last minute of cooking time.  The celery I added with the carrots.  I also added 1 tsp of lemon   pepper to brighten the flavor of the soup.  I'm going to be making this soup again, for sure!!  Thanks for a GREAT recipe!

text:
I make this at least twice a month. It is sooo tasty. very flavorful. They only change I've made is using regular breakfast sausage instead of Italian sausage. So if you're not an Italian sausage fan you can still enjoy this soup! Some tasty options to add as sides or condiments: my fianc loves to put sour cream in his, I like to add Feta cheese to mine and sometimes we split an avocado as a side. I don't know why but they really go together well. Another thing I like about this dish is the zuchinni. It has a potato like texture but it's not starchy so for the ones that like the tradition of potatoes in your stew you have that sort of fix.

Best winter soup ever! I sometimes sub chopped kale instead of spiniach, I usually double recipe for my family but only use 1 can northern beans, and keep Kale or Spiniach to 2-3 cups depending on mood. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this last night, and now I'm currently eating leftovers, and this is AMAZING. The only changes I made was adding a good pinch of red pepper flakes, since our store was out of hot italian sausages, I had to use mild, and I added some basic seasonings (italian seasoning, pinch of basil & oregano, garlic powder.) Also added some tomato paste and 2 cans of beans instead of one. Anytime I make a tomato-ish dish I always add a small pinch of sugar, and it helped balance all the savory that was going on. This soup has amazing flavor, not to mention how fast and easy it was. I'm 19, and I'm the main cook in my family, since I enjoy it so much and my brother isn't crazy about a lot of vegetables, and my mom isn't crazy about a lot of meat, but they both really enjoyed this. Definitely going on meal rotation, and I can't wait to make a big batch in the summer with fresh in season vegetables and freeze it for the winter. This recipe is a 11/10!!

I love this easy quick recipe. Sometimes I add different fresh veggies whatever I have on hand. This is also an easy recipe for a crockpot. Just saute garlic and sausage and then put in crockpot. Add all the remaining ingredients except spinach. Set on high for 4-6 hours add spinach 5 minutes before serving. Easy make ahead recipe.

text:
Versatile, tasty soup. Made many times, often with subs, like chicken stock, not beef, one link of a flavorful sausage (as from Sprouts) and a half pound fresh grnd beef, different beans that I have on hand, always with lots of spinach. To round out the deep, sultry flavor, I add a 1/4th to 1/2 stick of butter...zowies. Some recipes include Parmesan cheese as a garnish...yummy, but not needed, if you are (ahem...) watching extra calories.

Cooker Jack

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this soup last night for supper and it was wonderful. My husband commented several times how good it was.   I doubled the recipe so that I could freeze some for later and other than that, the only changes from the original recipe I made were omitting the salt and being a little heavy handed on the garlic.  Eating the soup alone, it could have used a little salt but it was fine without.  (Not knowing how salty my sausage was, I didn't want to overdo it and could add it at the end, if necessary.) Since we typically eat soup with crackers, we didn't need additional salt.  Changes I would make the next time I make it:  add more beans or pasta.  We like a thick, hearty soup and additional beans or pasta would thicken it up a bit.   If I have extra spinach, I will add it.  Not that it needed more, but anytime I can add more greens is a bonus.  We like our foods spicy and considered using half sweet Italian sausage/half hot Italian sausage, but I'm not a huge hot Italian sausage fan.  May try adding a little cayenne the next time...but it is delicious as is!  Great recipe!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1990247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This "Italian Sausage Soup" is the perfect comfort food: very delicious broth loaded with Italian sausage, orange round carrot slices, white zucchini cubes, dark green pieces of spinach, and cream-colored beans. I made mine with homemade chicken stock (instead of beef broth) because I took it out of the freezer by mistake. I also used "Italian White Spagna Beans" (instead of Great Northern Beans) because that is all I could find at the Italian grocery store, and they look like the same thing to me. I could not bring myself to put the bean liquid from the can into the soup. The next time I make this soup I will prepare the vegetables in advance because this soup comes together very fast (good for a busy day). Also, I will use precooked Italian sausage pieces from the freezer since I always have them on hand (usually for quick breakfasts). I will certainly make this recipe again many, many more times. Thank you SALLYJUN for sharing your recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup is awesome!  I fixed it during the Thanksgiving holiday when family was in town.  Everyone raved about it and it was super easy to make.  For those with a King Soopers nearby, I got their 18 oz. package of spicy Italian sausage and used the whole package.  I also used an entire 32 oz. box of organic beef broth (my sister is big on organic stuff).  Cutting the zucchini in chunks keeps them from getting too mushy.  My brother-in-law who likes things spicy and always adds cayenne to everything said the spice from the sausage was just right.  Last night, I made the soup again with left over chicken broth, wilting spinach, and half a package of spicy sausage.  It still came out great! It's the kind of soup that you can really improvise as long as you have good tasting sausage.  Next time I think I will try kale.

text:
This recipe was absolutely delicious!  I made a few additions to incorporate some veggies I already had in my refrigerator.  I used sweet Italian turkey sausage, added 1/2 an onion, 1 small yellow squash, 1 rib of celery, 1/2 of a turnip - cubed, used 6 cloves of garlic, added in some water (1 broth can ) and a beef bullion cube, and seasoned with onion flakes, garlic flakes, and Italian seasoning in addition to the salt and pepper.  I simmered the soup on low for about 5 hours and served it over cooked salad macaroni (ditalini).  I'll be making this recipe for years to come!

I've made it, subbed kale for spinach when that's what's we had on hand, and used black beans if we're out of white.  It's always a hit - and my 2.5 year old will eat all the veggies!  (She demands more radishes!)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe!! I took the advice from some other reviewers and tweaked a bit of the ingredients around to round out the flavors. I added one chopped onion, 1 cubed red potato, about 1 tsp oregano, increased the garlic from 1 to 3 cloves, added a bit of ditalini at the end, changed the broth to 32 oz of beef stock, cut out the salt, and used half sweet, half hot sausage. I would recommend using all hot sausage as that had the best flavor and using diced tomatoes rather than the stewed tomatoes. The spinach and zucchini are great additions to this recipe and it's really a keeper!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2014-02-19T09:50:26.22
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
639797
Display Name:
cookin_mommi
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
71
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious!  The nice thing about this is that you can tweak it as you like.  I followed the recipe almost exactly, but I added some chopped celery along with the garlic when I browned the sausage.  I chopped the canned stewed tomatoes so my tomato chunks wouldn't be so big (but I still added all the liquid from the can).  When I added the spinach at the end, I also added about 2 cups of cooked ditalini pasta.  For that reason, there wasn't quite enough broth, so I had to add more.  The flavor from the sausage and the italian-style tomatoes was plenty of seasoning for us.  I did not add any salt or pepper - not needed.  I recommend waiting until it's done and tasting it before you add salt - mine was plenty salty without adding more.  Next time I would drain the fat after browning the sausage; I don't think it would detract from the flavor but would reduce the fat content.  I served with parmesan to sprinkle on top and warm rolls right out of the oven and everyone in our family of 6 liked it!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
This was the best soup I have had in a long while. Was proud to serve this for dinner.  I used 1LB of sweet italian sausage, replaced great northern beans with Canelli Beans (white kidney bean) added 1c of small shell pasta, because of the additon of the pasta I did add a third can of broth. I followed the advice of others and used low sodium broth and didn't add the additional 1/4tsp. Served this with very toasty garlic bread cut into strips for dipping. Next time will garnish with croutons and parm cheese. This is a great recipe and I enjoyed both cooking and eating this soup. Thanks

text:
This was a really good base recipe. I love hearty soups, so I added some extra oomph by adding cubed potatoes (during the cooking time of the beans and zucchini) as well adding 1 Cup dry uncooked orzo (at the same time of the potatoes). I had chicken broth, so I used that instead. I added an extra can since I added starch from potatoes and pasta. I wasn't sure if I would like it, since it has sausage in it, but I even loved it. I'm going to keep this in my keeper book for the future. The good thing about a recipe like this, is you can adapt it to your taste. I bet kale or cabbage would taste excellent in place of the spinach.

Very tasty soup, perfect for a chilly winter's day. I added some orzo to mine, but unfortunately I must've added a bit too much (1/2 c. uncooked) because it absorbed a lot of the liquid and ended up being more of a stew. Next time, I'd add less, or else cook it before adding. However, the recipe was very tasty as written! I used frozen spinach instead of fresh, I think it would be great either way. text:
Great soup for a cold day.  Made a double batch (2 lbs of mild sausage but will add a couple of links of hot next time),used chicken broth instead of beef, crushed tomatoes cause that's all I had on hand (added basil and oregano to the soup), extra zucchini, garbonzo beans instead of navy(that's what was in the pantry), and frozen spinach.  I first cooked the sausauge links and then thinly sliced them adding them to the soup with the other vegtables.  Added the spinach after I removed the heat, let sit for 10 minutes, and it was perfect. Served with salad and bread and the family loved it.  Thanks for a great recipe.

I tried this recipe, but made a few changes; I didn't have Zucchini so I used Red Bell Pepper, I also added 5 small potato's chopped into small cubes, 1 small minced onion, a small can of tomato paste, 3 cans of water and a tablespoon of Italian seasoning.  I got a little crazy, and added some chopped up left over meat loaf.  My husband is not a fan of Northern beans, so I added French style green beans.  I served it with Fresh Italian bread.  Absolutely delicious!

Not bad. This is a mildly flavored soup but you can add whatever spices you like to suit your tastes. I added a teaspoon of Italian seasoning to mine. NOTE: This makes a TON of soup and doesn't really reheat well.... The zucchini turn to mush so keep that in mind if you add it to your soup. All in all, this was decent, but not one of the best recipes for Italian soup on this site. Thanks anyways, SALLYJUN.

text:
This recipe is excellent. I served this for my boyfriend and his mother and they both loved it! I didn't change anything about the portions, but I did substitute the spinach for kale because I was originally looking for a Portuguese kale soup and this recipe is almost the same as kale soup recipes. I also used sweet-hot Italian sausage from Johnsonville, which added a nice kick. The only criticism I have, which could be easily amended, is that it was a little too salty. I would suggest using low-sodium broth like Blender Woman suggests or eliminating the added salt (or salting to taste). This recipe was also very easy to make. It's going on the regular dinner rotation now!

There's a pot of this soup simmering on the stove right now at my house.  We absolutely love it!  I make the soup in 2 stages. I follow the recipe exactly but stop before adding the zucchini, parsley, and pasta. I cool it in the fridge overnight or for a day or two. text:
This is an excellent recipe (surprising sweet) that everyone loved.  Its only problem is not enough liquid.  I supplemented using an additional can of tomatoes and some additional broth. Other than adding one medium onion (chopped) in with the sausage, the addition of liquid was the only change I made. This was the first time I've used canned Italian tomatoes and I'm glad I did.  I wasn't sure they were that different from other canned tomatoes, but they were.  In addition to the spices, the tomatoes included tomatoe juice.  I think this helped to make the soup and if you haven't tried it, certainly try in this recipe.

text:
IF I make this soup again...  I liked the basic ingredients and the ease, but we found it a bit too salty.  I used low
sodium beef broth even, but next time would omit the 1/4 tsp. salt too, and even look for no-salt added stewed tomatoes.  Italian sausage is salty enough.  I'd drain the sausage well before adding the other ingredients, and I'd drain (and rinse) the beans before adding, because I could taste the bean sauce in the soup - don't care for that taste.  I knew hubby would pick out the spinach, so didn't add that.

Definitely the perfect meal for a cold winter day!  I made this tonight and only made a few slight changes.  I used 1lb of lean, hot Italian turkey sausage. I removed it from the casing and sauteed it. Because I threw in a half a cup of Ditalini pasta, I added an extra cup of the organic beef stock that I used. I did not add any salt since the stock wasn't low-sodium.  The soup tastes fantastic! The spicy sausage gave the broth such a nice, rich flavor! I will absolutely be making this again.

This soup is fantastic and freezes well. I added extra chicken broth, 1 can whole tomatoes and 1 can crushed tomatoes, frozen spinach instead of fresh, 1 cubed potato. I also used hot italian sausage to give it some kick. Delicious!

text:
I really liked this recipe for the winter months when everyone is getting sick.  Hearty & packed with vitamins.  It's so easy to add any veggies you have handy!  I added half an onion, 3 sweet potatoes, and some elbow macaroni to the 4 zucchini, 1 1/2 lbs of carrots and spinach (the recipe was more than doubled). I added the beef broth and then just water to increase the soup:goodies ratio and reduce the saltiness of the broth.  Half spicy/half mild sausage was great.  The spice from the sausage added enough flavor to the broth that I didn't use any additional salt or pepper.

text:
I had to make a few adjustments (otherwise I would have rated 5 stars) but my soup came out delicious! I added diced onion with the sausage and garlic. Next time I might try adding celery as well. I found the soup to be a bit bland so I added some Italian seasoning. I also added some good quality beef base to give it a richer flavor. I cooked elbow macaroni separately and added to each bowl as I served it. I must have it gluten free so that's the easiest way to accommodate myself and my family (they are pasta lovers). Everyone had seconds and it was a huge hit!

My soup ended up tasting like spinach soup instead.  I had doubled the recipe anyway...and thought it would be fine.  I will try this again.  I really like soups w/out noodles..and with 1500 reviews, I  know it will be good...it I make a few adjustments.

text:
The only thing I did different was that I cooked the Italian sausage links in water on low till they were done. Let them cool, and sliced into pieces, and put into food processor, until the texture of ground beef. This way, you get sausage with each and every spoonful of soup. Other than that, this soup is every bit delicious.

text:
What a nice soup to have a cold fall evening. I made this soup for the first time today, and it will definitely be a keeper in my home. First off, I don't fry foods, so I cooked the sausage in the microwave, adding the garlic to the beef broth and tomato mixture. We like green beans, so I added those instead of Northern beans. I also added the zucchini, and carrots, and spinach. In the end, I added 1/2 cup elbow macaroni. We had a salad and rolls to complete our meal. There is enough for leftovers. DELICIOUS!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great platform for any italian-style soup. I used this recipe last night as a base for my own hodgepodge. Even before I began adding extra ingredients I found that it is necessary to have a minimum of 1 more can (about 1.5 cups) of broth. To boot, I read all the suggestions from other cooks and incorporated most of them, so I ended up needing much more liquid than the original recipe calls for (I lost track of the measurements after a while... part of what makes this a fun soup). Mine had a little of everything: mushrooms, rice, potatoes, pasta, red onion, LOTS of extra garlic, plus everything in the original recipe. It really does turn out more like a stew- an incredibly delicious italian-style stew! Definitely worth keeping around, especially for the fall/winter seasons.

text:
This soup is wonderful and easy. I had some Italian Sausage so I went browsing for a new recipe. I am a obsessive soup fan so I thought this would be the perfect recipe for an October night. I didn't have any of the other ingredients but after a fast stop at the market I had everything for under 10. We read over the other reviews and agreed that it could be changed for your own personal preference, but we thought for the 1st time making it we would just follow the recipe as is.It was so good,full of fresh vegetables. I wish I was still eating it. The flavor is perfect and I did add some red pepper flakes because I like a spicy soup but Hot Italian Sausage doesn't sit well in my stomach. I don't think I will change anything next time except maybe use turkey Italian Sausage to cut down on the fat. This soup is so yummy with fresh extra sourdough and a good red Italian wine. We had Chianti. I think I will be adding it to my list of favorites and many of them are soups! Thank you.

text:
I made a few alterations based on my family's tastes and the limitations of my pantry. I needed some extra liquid because I live at a high altitude, so I chose chicken broth. I also added chopped celery, and I didn't have beans on hand so I used diced potatoes instead. Unfortunately, I had to use frozen zucchini and spinach because I didn't have access to any fresh stuff that was in nice condition. Overall, the soup turned out a bit bland, but that might have just been the fault of the added liquid, so I added some dried basil and oregano to perk it up a bit. It turned out pretty good. A nice basic soup, easy to make and easy to modify.

text:
So great -but I used suggestions from others. First I used turkey italian sausage to reduce fat, used 2 cloves of garlic and added a small chopped onion, used cannellini beans instead of great northern,  and used potato cut into small chunks instead of the zucchini, used Ox's no-sodium beef broth packets & omitted the salt and it was still salty enough.  Last time I made it I threw in a handful of tiny pasta but it really doesn't need it -this is a filling soup full of vitamins.  The fresh spinach added at the end really makes it!

Display Name:
Karen

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I sauted all of the veggies and half a finely copped onion (with the exceptionof the spinach saved for last) in with the sausage after I drained off the fat.  I also used a 4 cup box of sodium reduced beef stock instead of the 2 cups listed in the recipe and added a 19 oz. can of Unico mixed bean medley (kidney beans, chick peas, black beans, etc) and 1/4 c. barley.  AWESOME.
Update 9/23/2011:  I have made it again with reconstituted mixed dry beans instead of the canned [less sodium] and kale instead of spinach [keeps its shape & texture much better] which gets slimey.  Much better with these modifications.
Review:
Rating:
5

favoritesCount:
84
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this soup as lunch for me and my boyfriend today, so I halved the recipe. I ditched the spinach and added a ricotta and spinach tortellini instead, to make it more filling. Used canned carrots and added those in with the beans and zucchini instead of the tomatoes (didn't want them to cook too long). Used low-sodium beef broth, and both hot and sweet sausages (would maybe just use hot next time). We both loved it and did not need to add any more spices - the beef broth (even low-sodium) and the stewed tomatoes provided plenty of salt and seasoning! I should have followed reviewer advice and added more broth, as I don't have much left for tomorrow's leftovers. With the tortellini added, and a small bit of bread on the side, this one dish kept us full until dinner. Will definitely be making again.
Review:

text:
Wonderful wintertime soup!
Changes we made:
40Oz of low sodium chicken broth instead of beef broth
2 (14.5oz) cans of zucchini with tomato instead of fresh zucchini
more than 1/4 teaspon ground black
no salt
added 1-2C COOKED small macaroni near end
Right before serving, add 1 14.5Oz can of Drained spinach

This really has a great flavor, I was pleasantly surprised. I am not a huge sausage fan so that is the only thing that I would cut back on.  I did like some others and added another can of stewed tomatoes and beans.  I didn't add more broth, I felt it had plenty liquid. I had a rotisserie chicken in the fridge that I just cut some chunks off and added at the last, also a potatoe, and some mushrooms when I was browning the sausage. I really liked the chicken in there.  Lots of things you could add to this soup, fun to tweak to your liking.

It had good flavor, and I was worried about it not being good up until I served it in the bowls. This was partly my fault though. I used sausages that I had on hand, which are much healthier b/c they are chicken sausages with red pepper (but they have no skin from which to crumble the meat, and they are fully cooked; just need warming). But it still turned out good. I too added an onion and an xtra clove of garlic. I am cautious of the sodium content though (even though I used low sodium organic broth), I feel there was much salt in the bean liquid and stewed toms. liquid. We did enjoy it though.

Display Name:
dean p.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is really a superb soup, although I did make some changes to suit my own taste.

Instead of Italian Sausage, I used Farmer John "Firehouse Hot" Pork Sausage. It's a 12 ounce sausage that imparts a great deal of flavor and spice. (It's also a way to lower the fat content of the soup for those, like me, who are watching their weight.) I added an additional clove of garlic because I like more garlic. 

Also, I replaced the zuchini and spinach with cabbage. I tore the cabbage up into large bit size pieces. The mild, sweet flavor of the cabbage presented a perfect counterbalance to the zesty heat of the sausage.

I couldn't recommend this soup more strongly!!! I will be making it again very soon and anticipate that it will become part of the regular rotation of soups in our home.

So, go ahead and make this excellent soup. You won't be disappointed.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2004-11-08T05:09:03.327
